title: Front Headlock Go Behind
description: Technique to move from front headlock to back control

move steps.description: Secure a tight front headlock position with one arm around the opponent's head and your other hand controlling their far arm.
Step your lead foot back, creating space between you and your opponent.
Quickly circle around to your opponent's back, maintaining control of their head and arm.
As you move behind them, release the headlock and slide your arm under their near armpit.
Establish back control by securing your hooks (feet inside their thighs) and applying a seatbelt grip around their upper body.

mediaObject.gif: ./public/media/gifs/Attacking the Back Front Headlock Go Behind.gif
mediaObject.imageSmall: public/media/images/Attacking the Back Front Headlock Go-Behind.png

title: Turtle Position to Back Mount
description: Transition from controlling the turtle position to taking the back mount

move steps.description: From the turtle control position, secure a seatbelt grip around your opponent's upper body. One arm should be under their armpit, and the other over their shoulder.
Use your chest to apply pressure on your opponent's back, keeping them in the turtle position. Simultaneously, slide your knee on the under-hook side into their armpit.
Lift your opponent's hips by pulling up on the seatbelt grip and driving your knee forward. This will create space to insert your first hook (foot inside their thigh).
As your opponent's balance is compromised, quickly insert your second hook on the opposite side. Keep your chest pressure to prevent them from rolling.
Squeeze your knees together to secure the position, flatten your opponent onto their stomach, and adjust your seatbelt grip for optimal control in the back mount position.

mediaObject.gif: public/media/gifs/Attacking the Back Turtle Position to Back Mount.gif

title: Sliding Collar Choke
description: Execute a sliding collar choke from the back mount position

move steps.description: From the back mount position with a seatbelt grip, use your top hand to grab the collar on the far side of your opponent's neck. Your thumb should be inside the collar, fingers out.
Slide this grip deep into the collar, aiming to get your hand past your opponent's far ear. Keep your elbow tight to their back to prevent defense.
Bring your second hand under your first arm and grab the near side of the collar. Again, thumb in, fingers out.
Pull both hands towards you, creating tension in the collar. Your elbows should be pointing down, not flared out.
To finish, slide your second hand up towards your first hand while pulling both hands towards your chest. Simultaneously, arch your back and squeeze your elbows together to increase pressure.

title: Mount to Back Mount and Rear Naked Choke
description: Transition from mount to back mount and apply a rear naked choke

title: Scissor Sweep
position: Closed Guard Bottom: Collar and Elbow Control
description: Execute a scissor sweep from closed guard using collar and elbow control

move steps.description: From closed guard, establish a cross collar grip with one hand and a same-side sleeve grip with your other hand.
Open your guard and place the foot on the sleeve-grip side on your opponent's hip. Your other leg should be bent with the foot on the mat.
Pull on the collar to bring your opponent forward, disrupting their balance. Simultaneously, push their arm across their body using your sleeve grip.
As you pull and push, swing your leg from their hip across their body, placing your shin across their midsection. Your other leg should come up behind their back.
Use your grips to pull your opponent towards the side of your leg that's across their body. At the same time, push with your shin and lift with your leg behind their back to sweep them over.

mediaObject.gif: public/media/gifs/Closed Guard Collar and Elbow Control Scissor Sweep.gif
mediaObject.imageSmall: public/media/images/Closed Guard Collar and Elbow Control Scissor Sweep (1).png
mediaObject.imageLarge: public/media/images/Closed Guard Collar and Elbow Control Scissor Sweep (2).png

title: Shoulder Trap Armbar
position: Closed Guard Bottom: Collar and Elbow Control
description: Apply an armbar from closed guard using collar and elbow control

move steps.description: From closed guard, secure a cross collar grip with one hand and a same-side sleeve grip with your other hand. Ensure your collar grip is deep with your thumb inside the collar.
Use your collar grip to pull your opponent forward, breaking their posture. Simultaneously, push their arm across their body using your sleeve grip.
As your opponent's posture breaks, quickly release your collar grip and wrap that arm over their shoulder and behind their head, trapping their shoulder.
Open your guard and slide your hips out to the side of the trapped arm. Your leg on the same side as the trapped arm should come up high on your opponent's back.
Swing your other leg over your opponent's head to set up the armbar. Pinch your knees together, lie back, and extend your hips to finish the armbar submission.

title: Triangle Choke
position: Closed Guard Bottom: Collar and Elbow Control
description: Apply a triangle choke from closed guard using collar and elbow control

move steps.description: Grip your opponentâ€™s collar with your right hand and control their left elbow with your left hand.
Pull the collar and elbow to break their posture and bring their head close to you.
Place your left foot on their right hip and shoot your right leg over their neck.
Grab your right shin with your left hand and lock your left leg under your right knee.
Adjust the angle by pulling their head down, squeeze your knees together, and push up with your left foot to tighten and complete the choke.

title: Over the Back Posture Control
description: Control your opponent's posture in closed guard by reaching over their back

move steps.description: From closed guard, reach over your opponent's back and grab their belt with one hand (let's say your right hand).
With your left hand, control your opponent's opposite sleeve to prevent them from posting and to manage their posture.
Use your belt grip to pull your opponent forward, keeping your legs closed around them to break their posture.
Shift your hips out slightly to the side opposite your belt grip while maintaining the pressure with your legs and grip.
Use your free hand to attack, such as going for a collar choke or setting up a sweep, while keeping control with your belt grip and maintaining posture control with your legs and sleeve grip.

title: Closed Guard Over the Back Posture Control - Head Outside Attacks
description: Attack options when controlling posture with head outside in closed guard

title: Headlock Defence to Back Mount
description: Escape from a headlock in closed guard to take the back

move steps.description: As your opponent attempts a headlock, stay calm and frame against their face or throat to create space.
With your free hand, grab their wrist or arm and begin to pry it off from your neck.
As you break the headlock, shift your hips out to one side and slide your arm around their waist.
Climb onto their back, using your legs to control their hips while you transition to back mount.
Secure your hooks and establish a dominant back control position, transitioning to a submission if desired.

title: Pin Escape vs Hip Clamp
description: Escape when opponent pins you in closed guard with a hip clamp

move steps.description: When your opponent clamps down on your hips to control your movement, quickly frame against their chest with one arm.
Use your other hand to control their arm or wrist, preventing them from advancing their position.
Shrimp your hips out to one side, creating space between their clamp and your hips.
As you create space, quickly adjust your guard, either regaining closed guard or transitioning to open guard.
If available, look to set up a sweep or submission once youâ€™ve escaped the hip clamp.

title: Pin vs Forearm across the Throat
description: Defend against opponent's forearm across your throat in closed guard

move steps.description: From closed guard, your opponent pins your head with one of their arms. Use both hands to control their wrist and forearm of the arm pinning your head.
Open your guard and place your foot on the same side as the trapped arm onto their hip, creating a pivot point for your hips.
Using your other leg, swing it out and around, elevating your hips. Simultaneously, push off their hip with your foot and begin to turn your body to face their back.
Release the arm control and shoot your top arm under their armpit while bringing your other arm over their shoulder to secure a seatbelt grip or double-under hooks.
Complete the transition to back mount by sliding your bottom leg through and placing both hooks in, controlling their hips with your legs.

title: Armbar Vs Two Handed Choke
description: Apply an armbar when opponent attempts a two-handed choke in your closed guard

move steps.description: As your opponent reaches for a two-handed choke, quickly trap one of their arms by grabbing their wrist.
Post one foot on their hip and angle your body to the side, preparing to pivot for the armbar.
Swing your opposite leg over their head while controlling their wrist tightly.
Use your hips to lift your body and pull their arm straight, applying pressure for the armbar.
Finish by extending your hips upward and securing their arm between your legs for the submission.

title: Posture Control - Inverted Armbar
description: Apply an inverted armbar from closed guard

move steps.description: From closed guard, break your opponentâ€™s posture by pulling them forward and securing their arm.
Slide your hand underneath their arm, gripping their tricep or gi sleeve to control their elbow.
Pivot your body to the side, bringing your hips closer to their arm to angle for the submission.
Place one leg over their shoulder and the other across their torso, tightening your control.
Pull their arm towards your body while elevating your hips, applying pressure for the inverted armbar.

title: Posture Control to Triangle Choke
description: Transition from posture control to a triangle choke in closed guard

title: Defence of Front Bodylock (Under the Arms)
description: Defend against a front bodylock where the opponentâ€™s arms are under yours, allowing you to break free or counter-attack.

move steps.description: When your opponent secures a bodylock under your arms, immediately lower your center of gravity by bending your knees to avoid being lifted.
Frame against their hips with both hands to create space and prevent them from closing the gap or completing a takedown.
Widen your stance to further stabilize yourself and make it harder for the opponent to off-balance or throw you.
Use one hand to push their head or chin upward, destabilizing their posture and preventing them from controlling your upper body effectively.
Step one leg back while maintaining pressure on their hips or head, which will help you rotate out of their grip.
As you break free from their hold, immediately create distance by stepping back or transitioning into a counter-attack, such as an underhook or a clinch.

title: Defence of Side Headlock Backward Trip (Tani Otoshi)
description: Defend against a side headlock where the opponent attempts a backward trip (Tani Otoshi) and counter or escape the position.

move steps.description: When your opponent secures a side headlock and begins attempting the backward trip (Tani Otoshi), immediately lower your base by bending your knees and widening your stance to maintain balance.
Frame with your outside hand against their hip or ribs to prevent them from pulling you off balance and completing the trip.
With your inside hand, control their far wrist or elbow, reducing their ability to finish the throw and keeping their upper body in check.
Shift your weight towards the side of the headlock to prevent them from pulling you backward, and step your leg closest to them forward to counterbalance.
Once your balance is stabilized, begin to straighten your posture and push into them, using your grip on their hip and wrist to loosen their headlock control.
As they lose leverage, free your head by turning it toward their body and pulling it out of the headlock. From here, you can transition to an underhook, back control, or disengage to create distance.

title: Closed Guard Posture control with Head and Arm - Overview
description: Overview of controlling posture with head and arm control in closed guard

move steps.description: From the closed guard position, break your opponentâ€™s posture by pulling them down with your legs and securing an arm around their head.
With one arm, grip around the back of their neck or head, pulling them closer to your chest.
Use your other hand to control their arm by gripping their tricep or sleeve, limiting their ability to post or create distance.
Keep your legs engaged by squeezing your knees together to maintain control and prevent them from posturing back up.
Adjust your angle if needed by shifting your hips slightly to one side to gain better leverage for sweeps or submission attempts.
Maintain head and arm control to set up potential transitions such as an armbar, triangle choke, or a sweep depending on your opponent's movement.

title: Closed Guard Posture control with Head and Arm - Transition to Back Mount
description: Transition from closed guard with head and arm control to back mount

title: Closed Guard Posture Overview
description: Overview of proper posture and positioning in closed guard

move steps.description: From the closed guard position, maintain a strong grip on your opponent's collar with one hand, while your other hand controls their sleeve on the opposite side.
Open your guard by unlocking your legs, placing one foot on the mat, and pivoting your hips to the side while pulling your opponent's sleeve across their body.
As you pivot, slide your leg under your opponentâ€™s armpit, creating leverage. Your other leg swings out wide, ready to assist in sweeping.
Lift your opponentâ€™s arm while simultaneously pulling their collar and swinging your leg to knock them off balance, using your hips and the momentum of your leg swing to tip them over.
Follow through by using the momentum to rotate on top of your opponent, securing the mount or side control as they land on their back.

title: Flower Sweep
description: Execute a flower sweep against an opponent in kneeling posture

title: Hip Bump Sweep
description: Execute a hip bump sweep against an opponent in kneeling posture

move steps.description: From closed guard, sit up quickly by releasing your legs and posting one hand on the mat behind you for support.
At the same time, use your free arm to reach over and control your opponentâ€™s arm, keeping it close to their body.
Drive your hips forward and into your opponent, aiming to bump their chest with your hip to create momentum.
Use your posted hand to push off the mat while pulling your opponentâ€™s arm across their body.
As you rotate your hips, use the momentum to sweep your opponent over, landing in the mount position.

title: Handstand Sweep (Lumberjack Sweep)
description: Execute a handstand sweep against a standing opponent

move steps.description: When your opponent stands in your closed guard, secure a strong grip on both of their ankles.
Unlock your legs and place both feet on your opponentâ€™s hips to control their posture.
Lift your hips off the ground using your grips on their ankles for balance, creating a â€˜handstandâ€™ motion.
At the height of your motion, pull their ankles toward you while pushing their hips with your legs, causing them to fall backward.
Once your opponent falls, follow them up by climbing to a standing position or moving into a dominant top position.

title: Lumberjack Sweep to Step-over Armbar
description: Transition from a handstand sweep to a step-over armbar

move steps.description: Begin by gripping both of your opponentâ€™s ankles as they stand in your closed guard.
Use the Handstand Sweep by lifting your hips and pulling your opponentâ€™s ankles forward while pushing their hips to sweep them to the ground.
As your opponent falls, immediately shift your body to the side, isolating one of their arms.
Swing your leg over your opponentâ€™s head, trapping the arm as you sit back to secure the armbar position.
Control their wrist and apply pressure by extending your hips upward to finish the armbar submission.

title: Kneeling Guard Break
description: Break the opponentâ€™s closed guard from a kneeling position.

move steps.description: Start in your opponentâ€™s closed guard with good posture, keeping your elbows tight to your body.
Use your hands to grip your opponentâ€™s collar with one hand and their hip or pants with the other, controlling their posture and preventing attacks.
Shift your weight back while maintaining control of their hips, using your elbows to apply pressure on their inner thighs.
Once their legs begin to weaken, slide one knee up in the center of their tailbone while keeping the other leg kneeling for stability.
Push your hips backward and maintain pressure with your knee to force their legs apart, breaking their guard.
After the guard opens, immediately begin your guard pass, maintaining control of their hips to prevent recovery.

title: Stiff Arm Closed Guard Break
description: Break your opponentâ€™s closed guard using stiff-arm pressure to force their legs open.

move steps.description: Begin in your opponentâ€™s closed guard with a strong base, keeping your hips back and posture upright.
Place both hands on your opponentâ€™s hips or belt, applying stiff-arm pressure to keep them from breaking your posture.
Straighten your arms and push your hips backward while using your bodyweight to apply downward pressure on their hips.
Simultaneously, posture up by raising your chest and shoulders to force your opponent's guard open.
Once their legs open, slide one knee forward between their legs to begin a guard pass, keeping control of their hips to prevent re-engagement.

title: Guard Passing Overview: Four Foundational Guard Passes
description: Overview of four fundamental guard passing techniques

title: Half Guard Knee Cut Pass
description: Pass the guard using a knee cut technique

move steps.description: Start in top half guard, with your far-side arm securing an underhook on the opponent and your near-side hand controlling their collar or framing against their shoulder.
Position your trapped leg so that your knee is pointed outward, preparing for the knee cut pass. Drive your knee into their thigh or hip to create pressure.
Flatten your opponent by applying shoulder pressure with your underhook side, pinning their upper body to the mat and limiting their mobility.
Use your free hand to control their far-side arm, either pinning it to the mat or keeping it trapped, preventing them from framing or blocking your pass.
Start the knee cut motion by sliding your trapped legâ€™s knee across their body, aiming toward the mat on the far side of their hip. Maintain upper body pressure throughout.
Free your foot from their half guard by using a windshield wiper motion or kicking out while your knee is cutting across, keeping your weight balanced forward.
As your knee clears their guard, settle into side control by securing your far-side underhook, flattening them out, and establishing strong chest-to-chest pressure.

title: Guard Top: Straight Foot Lock
description: Apply a straight foot lock from the top position

title: Half Guard: Pass to Mount (7 Point Pass)
description: A systematic guard pass from top half guard position, using seven points of control to progress from half guard to mount.
starting grips: Control on Opponentâ€™s Upper Body and Hips

move steps.description: Start in top half guard, establish an underhook with your far arm (opposite to the side of the trapped leg) while maintaining chest pressure on your opponent.
Use your free hand to control your opponentâ€™s near-side hip, preventing them from regaining guard or shrimping away.
Flatten your opponent by driving your shoulder into their chest while simultaneously pinning their hips with your other hand.
Free your trapped knee by sliding it out of their half guard, using a windshield-wiper motion with your leg, and planting your foot on the mat.
Once your knee is free, drive it across their body toward their far hip, placing your knee near their stomach to stabilize and further control their hips.
Transition your upper body control by sliding your far-side arm (the one with the underhook) across to the other side of their head, shifting your weight for balance.
Complete the pass by swinging your free leg over their body, establishing full mount. Maintain pressure and establish a solid base once you achieve the mount.

title: Half Guard: Pass to Side Control (Knee Cut Pass)
description: Pass the half guard to side control using a knee cut pass

title: Open Guard: Double Wrist Control to Overhead Sweep
description: Execute an overhead sweep from double wrist control in open guard

move steps.description: From open guard, control both of your opponentâ€™s wrists while placing your feet on their hips to maintain distance.
Kick your legs upward to lift your opponent off the ground while maintaining wrist control, pulling them toward you.
As they are lifted, tuck your legs under them and kick upward, flipping them over your head.
Follow the momentum of the sweep, releasing their wrists and coming on top into a mount or dominant position.
Secure your top position, ensuring you maintain control of your opponentâ€™s body to prevent an immediate counter.

title: Open Guard vs Standing: Double Wrist Control to Tripod Sweep
description: Execute a tripod sweep from double wrist control against a standing opponent

move steps.description: From open guard, control both of your opponentâ€™s wrists and place one foot on their hip to create distance.
Hook your other foot behind their ankle, ensuring you maintain a strong grip on their wrists to control their posture.
Push with your foot on their hip while simultaneously pulling their wrist forward and sweeping their ankle out from under them.
As they fall, release the wrist grips and come up on top, following the momentum of the sweep.
Establish a secure top position, such as side control or mount, as you complete the tripod sweep.

title: Half Guard Pin: Guard Recovery
description: Recover full guard from a pinned half guard position

title: Pin control: Overview of Dominant Positions
description: Overview of controlling techniques from dominant pin positions

title: Side Control to Mount Transition
description: Transition from side control to mount

title: Side Control: Kata Gatame (Head and Arm Choke)
description: Apply a kata gatame (head and arm choke) from side control

move steps.description: From side control, secure your opponentâ€™s head and near-side arm by wrapping your arm around their neck and trapping their arm against your chest.
Lower your head toward the mat while shifting your weight to their far-side shoulder, tightening your grip on their neck and arm.
Lock your hands together in a gable grip or figure-four configuration, ensuring the pressure remains on their neck and arm.
Slide your body off to the side and drop your chest down while squeezing your arms, creating tight pressure around their neck.
Finish the choke by tightening your grip and driving your chest downward, cutting off the blood flow and forcing the submission.

title: Side Control: North South Choke
description: Apply a north-south choke from the north-south position

move steps.description: From side control, move your body toward a north-south position, wrapping one arm around your opponentâ€™s neck.
Drop your weight down onto your opponent's shoulders while locking your arm around their neck, trapping their head beneath your body.
Lock your hands together in a gable grip, positioning your arms tightly around their neck, cutting off blood flow to the brain.
Keep your weight low and drive your chest down onto their chest while tightening your grip around their neck.
Finish the choke by squeezing your arms and applying downward pressure with your chest, forcing the submission through suffocation or blood flow restriction.

title: Side Control: Armbar (Head Side Arm Grip)
description: Apply an armbar from side control using a head side arm grip

move steps.description: From side control, grip your opponentâ€™s near-side arm, controlling their wrist and elbow.
Slide your knee nearest their head toward their far-side shoulder while keeping pressure on their chest.
Swing your far-side leg over their head, placing it across their face while maintaining tight control of their arm.
Pinch your knees together around their arm and sit back, keeping their arm isolated and their thumb pointing upward.
Finish the armbar by pulling on their wrist and extending your hips to apply pressure on the arm, locking it for submission.

title: Side Control: Kimura (Shoulder Lock) from Armbar (Head Side Arm Grip)
description: Transition from an armbar attempt to a kimura in side control

move steps.description: From side control, secure your opponentâ€™s far-side arm by gripping their wrist with your hand and bringing their elbow away from their body.
Thread your far-side arm under their elbow and grab your own wrist, forming a figure-four grip to set up the Kimura lock.
Switch your hips, bringing your weight forward, and rotate their arm away from their body, while keeping tight control of their shoulder and wrist.
With their arm isolated, apply pressure by twisting their shoulder backward using the figure-four grip, while keeping their arm tight against your chest.
Finish the Kimura by extending and rotating their arm upward, applying pressure on the shoulder joint to secure the submission.

title: Headlock on the Ground (Kesa Gatame) Overview
description: Overview of the headlock on the ground (kesa gatame) position

title: Mount Top Overview
description: Overview of controlling techniques from the mount position

title: Mount: Keylock (Americana / Shoulder Lock)
description: Apply a keylock (americana) submission from mount

move steps.description: From mount, use both hands to control one of your opponentâ€™s wrists (let's say their right wrist) and pin it to the mat near their head. Your left hand should be gripping their wrist.
Slide your right hand under their arm and grab your own wrist, forming a figure-four lock with their arm.
Ensure your opponent's elbow is bent at a 90-degree angle and their knuckles are flat against the mat.
Begin to lift their elbow off the mat while keeping their wrist and knuckles pinned down. This isolates their shoulder joint.
Apply the submission by gradually pulling their elbow toward their head while lifting it off the mat. Maintain control and pressure until your opponent taps out.

title: Mount: Armbar vs Instinctive Opp (vs vertical push)
description: Apply an armbar from mount against an opponent pushing vertically

move steps.description: As your opponent pushes up with both arms, take advantage of the space they create by immediately trapping one of their arms.
Grab their wrist with one hand and place your other hand on their tricep to control the arm you're attacking.
Shift your weight towards their head while rotating your body to the side to bring your leg over their head.
Swing your leg over their face and sit back, keeping their arm tightly secured between your legs.
Extend your hips while pulling down on their arm to finish the armbar.

title: Mount: Armbar vs Instinctive Opp (vs lateral push)
description: Apply an armbar from mount against an opponent pushing laterally

move steps.description: As your opponent tries to push you off sideways, maintain control by gripping their arm and posting with your opposite hand for balance.
Shift your weight forward onto their chest, raising your hips slightly to prepare for the armbar.
Slide your knee closest to their head up towards their shoulder, trapping their arm and limiting their movement.
Swing your back leg over their head, ensuring it lands near their neck to secure the armbar position.
Sit back and extend your hips while controlling their arm with both hands to apply pressure and finish the armbar.

title: Back Door Escape
description: Escape side control by slipping out from under head and arm control through the 'back door'.
starting grips: Frame on opponentâ€™s head and arm

move steps.description: Bridge into your opponent to create space, pushing their arm upward while keeping your head tucked close to their chest.
Shrimp your hips to the outside while framing their arm with your hands, pushing it toward your head.
As their grip loosens, slip your head and shoulders underneath their arm, escaping from their control.
Roll out through the 'back door' and come up to your knees, ensuring you maintain posture to defend against further attacks.
Secure a dominant position, such as a single-leg or guard, after successfully escaping from side control.

title: Escape to the Knees, Single Leg
description: Escape side control by bringing your knees under you and transitioning to a single-leg grip.
starting grips: Frame on opponentâ€™s head and hips

move steps.description: From side control, frame against your opponentâ€™s head and hip using your arms, creating space for movement.
Bridge and shrimp your hips to the outside, sliding your near-side knee underneath you to create a base.
Push your opponentâ€™s weight upward while sliding your hips back, bringing yourself to your knees and aiming for a single-leg grab.
Control their leg by wrapping your arms around it tightly, driving forward with your body to destabilize them.
Finish the escape by standing up with the single-leg grip, transitioning to a takedown or continuing to advance position.

title: Side Control Guard Recovery
description: Escape side control by framing and recovering to guard.
starting grips: Frame on opponentâ€™s head and hips

move steps.description: Frame against your opponentâ€™s head and hips to create space, keeping your arms between you and their upper body.
Bridge your hips upward and shrimp away, creating enough space to slide your near-side knee inside their body.
Use your bottom leg to slide under their hips and begin reestablishing guard by hooking your leg around their waist.
Shrimp again if necessary, creating further space for your other leg to pass through and complete guard recovery.
Close your guard around their waist or establish an open guard, regaining full control and neutralizing their side control position.

title: Running Escape
description: Escape side control by using a running escape to create space and recover a neutral position.

move steps.description: From side control, turn your hips away from your opponent, framing against their body with your hands to create space.
Slide your legs out from underneath their pressure, turning onto your knees and using your hands to push off the mat.
Use your legs to 'run' or slide out from underneath their control, bringing your far-side leg to a more defensive position.
Shrimp your hips and continue moving away from their pressure until you are able to create enough space to free your body.
Recover guard or stand up into a more neutral position, defending against further attacks as you regain control.

title: Mount: Ezekiel choke
description: Apply an Ezekiel choke from mount

move steps.description: From mount, start by dropping your chest close to your opponent's chest to maintain pressure and control their upper body.
Slide one hand behind your opponent's head and neck, reaching under their head and grabbing your own sleeve or gi near the wrist with your other hand (left hand).
With your left hand free, bring it around to the front of your opponent's neck and slide it under their chin, extending your fingers.
To apply the choke, use your right arm to pull your left hand deeper into their neck while simultaneously pushing your left forearm into their throat.
Maintain your weight on their chest and squeeze your arms together, creating a scissoring motion to tighten the choke and finish the submission.

title: Knee on belly drills
description: Practice drills for maintaining and transitioning from knee on belly

title: Knee on belly: Cross Choke
description: Apply a cross choke from knee on belly

move steps.description: From the knee-on-belly position, maintain strong pressure on your opponentâ€™s midsection, with your knee on their belly and your other foot posted on the mat.
Grip your opponentâ€™s collar with one hand, feeding your fingers deep inside the fabric to control their posture.
Use your free hand to grab the opposite side of their collar, forming a cross grip with both hands.
Tighten the choke by pulling both hands toward you, driving your wrists into the sides of their neck.
Lean forward slightly to apply additional pressure and complete the choke, maintaining your balance on their belly.

title: Knee on belly: Far Armbar
description: Execute an armbar on the far arm from knee on belly position

move steps.description: From knee-on-belly, control your opponentâ€™s far arm by gripping their wrist or sleeve.
Post your other hand on the mat near their head for balance, and slide your knee from their belly to their far-side shoulder.
Swing your other leg around their head, trapping their arm as you bring your hips close to their shoulder.
Pinch your knees together tightly, keeping their arm isolated as you lean back to extend their arm.
Apply the armbar by controlling their wrist and extending your hips upward, locking their arm in a straight position for the submission.

title: Knee on belly: Near Armbar
description: Execute an armbar on the near arm from knee on belly position

move steps.description: From knee-on-belly, control your opponentâ€™s near-side arm by gripping their wrist or sleeve.
Shift your weight to the far side of their body, creating space to slide your near-side knee around their head.
Bring your other leg over their chest, trapping their near-side arm between your legs.
Pinch your knees together to control their arm, making sure their thumb is pointing upward as you sit back.
Finish the armbar by pulling on their wrist and extending your hips upward, locking the arm for the submission.

title: Mount to Back Mount and Rear Naked Choke
description: Transition from mount to back mount and apply a rear naked choke

title: Mount: Bridge Escape
description: Escape from bottom mount using a bridge technique

move steps.description: From the mounted position, trap one of your opponent's arms by holding their wrist and pinning it to your chest.
Simultaneously trap their leg on the same side by hooking it with your foot.
Bridge your hips explosively upward, lifting your opponent off-balance.
As you bridge, roll to the side where your opponent's arm and leg are trapped.
Continue the motion until you land on top in your opponent's guard or a more dominant position.

title: Mount: Elbow/Knee Escape
description: Escape from bottom mount using elbow and knee movement

move steps.description: From the mounted position, bring your elbows close to your body, keeping them tight to your sides.
Bridge your hips upward to create space between your body and your opponent.
Slide your knee through the created space, using your elbow to frame against your opponent's thigh.
Once your knee is through, shrimp your hips to the side to free your other leg from under your opponent.
Recover to a half-guard or full guard position by continuing to shrimp and pull your leg free.

title: Mount: Kata Gatame (Arm Triangle choke)
description: Execute a Kata Gatame from the mount position

move steps.description: From mount, use your hands to isolate and pin one of your opponentâ€™s arms across their neck. You can achieve this by pushing their arm with your hand or by using your chest to move it across.
Once their arm is across their neck, drop your head to the mat on the same side as the trapped arm. Your head should be close to their neck and jawline, trapping their arm in place.
Slide your opposite arm (let's say your right arm) underneath their head and wrap it around their neck, reaching towards your biceps of your other arm.
Join your hands together by gripping your bicep with one hand and placing your other hand on their back. Ensure that your arms form a tight triangle around their neck and their trapped arm.

To complete the choke, squeeze your arms together, drop your hips low to the mat, and shift your weight towards their side, applying pressure. Hold the position until your opponent taps or you achieve the submission.

title: North South Control: Pendulum Escape (Elbows Outside)
description: Escape from North South position using a pendulum motion with elbows outside

move steps.description: From north-south control, position your elbows outside their body to create a strong frame and maintain space.
Swing your legs back and forth in a pendulum motion to generate momentum and create space.
Shrimp your hips out and use the momentum to slide your body away from your opponent.
Slide one of your legs under your opponentâ€™s body to recover half-guard or full guard, depending on the space youâ€™ve created.
Establish a secure guard position, ensuring you have control of your opponent's posture to prevent immediate counterattacks.

title: North South Control: Spinning Escape (Elbows Inside)
description: Escape from North South position using a spinning motion with elbows inside

move steps.description: From north-south control, position your elbows inside your opponentâ€™s hips, framing to prevent their weight from crushing you.
Bridge slightly to lift your opponentâ€™s weight, creating a small gap between their body and yours.
Turn your body and spin underneath them, using your arms to push off and create space as you rotate.
Once youâ€™ve turned, use your legs to recover guard or come up to a turtle position, depending on your control of the situation.
Secure your position, defending against further pressure or attacks as you transition to a neutral or advantageous position.

title: Pin control: Overview of Dominant Positions
description: Overview of controlling various dominant pinning positions

title: Self Defence in the Standing Position Overview
description: Overview of self-defense techniques from a standing position

title: Snatch single leg
description: Execute a snatch single leg takedown

move steps.description: Start by lowering your level and stepping in close to your opponent while reaching for their front leg.
Secure their leg by grabbing it just above the knee with both hands, ensuring your chest is tight against their thigh.
Lift the leg by driving upward with your hips, pulling their leg into your body to destabilize their balance.
Keep their leg tight to your chest and pivot to the side to further off-balance them, preparing for the finish.
Drive forward or sweep their standing leg to complete the takedown, keeping control of the leg to prevent escape.

title: Snatch single leg (Outside leg finish)
description: Execute a snatch single leg takedown with an outside leg finish

move steps.description: After securing your opponentâ€™s leg, step to the outside of their body to change the angle of attack.
Lift their leg higher, pulling it across your body to force their weight onto the opposite leg.
Drive forward and outward, pushing their leg toward the outside of their body while sweeping their standing leg.
As they begin to fall, use your shoulder to continue driving their weight downward, controlling their descent.
Finish in top position, ensuring you maintain control of their leg and hips to prevent an escape.

title: Snatch single leg (Outside step finish)
description: Execute a snatch single leg takedown with an outside step finish

move steps.description: With the single leg secured, step outside of your opponent's body, positioning your body to the side.
Lift their leg with your arms while stepping forward with your outside leg to break their balance.
Drive your shoulder into their torso and push their leg outward while stepping behind them with your outside leg.
Continue driving your body weight into their upper body, forcing them to the mat while maintaining leg control.
Land in a dominant position, securing top control as you complete the takedown.

title: Standing Grip Break Vs Wrist Control (Same side, Cross Grip, 2 on 1)
description: Break various standing grips including same side, cross grip, and 2-on-1

title: Standing Guillotine Defence
description: Defend against a standing guillotine choke attempt

move steps.description: As your opponent wraps their arm around your neck for a guillotine, posture up to prevent them from locking the choke tightly.
Use one hand to grab their wrist while the other hand pushes against their hip to create space.
Step toward their trapped leg and drive your shoulder into their chest to break their posture and weaken the choke.
Once the choke is loosened, push their arm off your neck and duck your head out to fully escape.
Transition to a dominant position, such as taking their back or moving into top control.

title: Standing High-elbow Guillotine
description: Execute a high-elbow guillotine choke from a standing position

move steps.description: From a standing position, wrap one arm around your opponentâ€™s neck, ensuring you lock their head under your arm.
Grip your opposite wrist or hand and lift your elbow high, ensuring it is pointed upwards to create a tight choking angle.
Drive your hips forward while lifting your elbow to tighten the choke, applying pressure to their neck.
If they drop to their knees, follow them down while keeping the choke locked, maintaining control of their body.
Squeeze tightly and apply downward pressure with your body to finish the choke, or transition to guard if necessary.

title: Submission Defence: Closed Guard Guillotine
description: Defend against a guillotine choke attempt from closed guard bottom

move steps.description: As your opponent wraps their arm around your neck for a guillotine, maintain posture by keeping your back straight and head high.
Grip their wrist or forearm with one hand to control the choking arm and reduce pressure on your neck.
Use your free hand to push on their hip, creating space to relieve some of the pressure from the choke.
Step your legs forward to increase your leverage and drive your shoulder into their chest, breaking their posture.
Once the choke loosens, pop your head out and immediately posture up, ready to pass guard or regain control.

title: High Step Escape
description: Escape from back mount using a high step technique to create space and potentially recover guard or half guard

move steps.description: Protect your neck and defend against choke attempts by keeping your chin tucked and using your hands to block collar grips or defend your neck.
Create space by pushing opponent's hooks (feet) away from your hips using your legs. Focus on one side at a time.
High step one leg over your opponent's leg on the same side you created space. This leg should come up and over their thigh.
Bridge your hips up and turn your body towards the side you stepped over. Use the momentum to start rolling to your side.
Continue the turning motion until you're facing your opponent. As you turn, work to establish either a full guard or half guard position.

title: Takedown Defense: Sprawl vs Single Leg Takedown
description: Defend against a single leg takedown using a sprawl

move steps.description: As your opponent shoots in for a single leg takedown, immediately sprawl by pushing your hips backward and dropping your weight on their upper body.
Use your hands to post on their shoulders or hips, maintaining pressure and preventing them from driving forward.
Circle your leg away from their grip while continuing to drive your hips downward.
Once their grip on your leg is broken, transition your hips over their back or to the side for a dominant position.
From here, you can take control of the back or secure top control to maintain a superior position.

title: Turtle Position - Bottom: Guard Recovery Escape
description: Escape from bottom turtle position to guard

title: Turtle Position Overview
description: Overview of the turtle position, including defensive and offensive strategies

title: Closed Guard Over the Back Posture Control - Head Outside Attacks
description: Attack options when controlling posture with head outside in closed guard

title: Pin Escape - Headlock Defence to Back Mount
description: Escape from a headlock in closed guard to take the back

move steps.description: Tuck your chin to protect your neck from the headlock, and use your inside hand to frame against their neck to relieve pressure.
Break their posture by pulling them towards you using your legs and hips, weakening their grip.
Swim your far arm inside their headlock, establishing an underhook to control their far side and nullify the headlock.
Perform a hip escape by pushing on their hip or knee, sliding your hips out to the opposite side of the underhook.
As you create space, use the underhook to move towards their back, sliding your bottom leg out and positioning yourself behind them.
Secure back control by establishing both hooks and locking in a seatbelt grip to control their upper body.

title: Pin Escape vs Arm Between the Legs
description: Escape when opponent pins you in closed guard with arm between the legs

move steps.description: When your opponent passes their arm between your legs, trap their wrist with your same-side hand to control it.
Use your other hand to grab the back of their gi or collar to maintain posture control.
Quickly shift your hips to the side and elevate your legs to disrupt their balance.
As you create space, rotate your hips and bring your leg over their trapped arm, freeing yourself from the pin.
Once free, regain closed guard or transition to a submission such as an armbar, depending on their position.

title: Guard Passing Overview: Four Foundational Guard Passes
description: Overview of four fundamental guard passing techniques

title: Guard Passing: Knee Cut Pass
description: Pass the guard using a knee cut technique

move steps.description: From inside your opponent's guard, control their legs and posture by gripping their pant legs or belt.
Post one foot on the ground outside of your opponent's hip while keeping your knee tight to their body.
Cut your opposite knee across their thigh, aiming to slice through their guard while keeping heavy pressure on their chest.
Use your upper body to block their head and shoulders, creating space for your leg to pass.
Once your knee clears their legs, slide through into side control, maintaining pressure on their hips and torso.

title: Guard Passing: Leg Staple Pass
description: Pass the guard using a leg staple technique

move steps.description: From inside your opponentâ€™s open guard, pin one of their legs to the mat by pushing their knee or ankle down.
Step your same-side leg over their pinned leg, stapling it to the mat with your shin.
Use your upper body to control their head or far shoulder, keeping their posture broken while your shin traps their leg.
Slide your other leg around their guard and establish control over their hips, keeping pressure down to prevent movement.
Complete the pass by moving into side control, maintaining strong grips and solid pressure on their upper body and hips.

title: Takedown Defense: Sprawl vs Double Leg Takedown
description: Defend against a double leg takedown using a sprawl

move steps.description: As your opponent shoots in for a double leg takedown, lower your center of gravity and immediately sprawl your legs back.
Drive your hips downward into their shoulders, preventing them from lifting your legs or completing the takedown.
Use your hands to post on their back or hips, maintaining pressure while keeping your legs as far back as possible.
Circle to the side while keeping your weight on them, breaking their grip on your legs.
Once their grip breaks, transition to a dominant position such as top control or take their back.
